Displays a list of survey results by patient, for selected survey
report.sqlStatement:
-- cleanup tmp table IF object_id('tempdb..##PatientSurveys') IS NOT NULL BEGIN DROP TABLE ##PatientSurveys END
-- create cache table of survey data SELECT DISTINCT s.PatientId, s.SurveyId, s.SurveyDateText INTO ##PatientSurveys FROM Surveys s INNER JOIN SurveyItems si ON s.SurveyId = si.SurveyId -- restrict to dataset INNER JOIN @Patients ON s.PatientId = Patients.PatientId -- dataset WHERE s.SurveyType = @SurveyType
DECLARE @dynamic_columns varchar(max) DECLARE @query varchar(max)
SELECT @dynamic_columns = STUFF( (SELECT ',[' + SurveyItemNum + ']' FROM ( SELECT SurveyItemNum FROM ( SELECT si.SurveyItemNum, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(PARTITION BY SurveyItemNum ORDER BY SurveyItemId DESC) AS Row FROM SurveyItems si INNER JOIN ##PatientSurveys s ON s.SurveyId = si.SurveyId ) a WHERE Row = 1 AND SurveyItemNum IS NOT NULL ) s FOR XML PATH('')), 1, 1, '')
--PRINT @dynamic_columns
SET @query = 'SELECT PtMRN AS [MRN], SurveyDateText AS [Date], ' + @dynamic_columns + ' FROM ( SELECT s.SurveyId, p.PatientId, p.PtMRN, SurveyDateText, SurveyItemNum, SurveyItemResult FROM ##PatientSurveys s INNER JOIN SurveyItems si ON s.SurveyId = si.SurveyId INNER JOIN Patients p ON s.PatientId = p.PatientId ) AS P PIVOT ( MIN(SurveyItemResult) FOR SurveyItemNum IN (' + @dynamic_columns +') ) AS PVT ORDER BY PtMRN'
--PRINT @query EXEC (@query)

common.label: How are these graphs created?
common.description: We obtain data from the institutional database and run it through statistical models to adjust each surgeons results for case mix. As a simple illustration of case mix adjustment, imagine that one surgeons cases were 70% high risk for complications and 30% low risk, whereas a colleague's case mix was 50:50. We might expect that the surgeon who had more high risk patients would have a higher rate of complications. To make the comparison a fair one, a statistical algorithm might compare each surgeon's outcome for low risk patients and separately for high risk patients, then combine the results. The statistical algorithms used for the graphs adjust results for many variables, rather than just risk of complications, but the principle is the same.

infoItem.label: How do I read these graphs? What do the colors indicate?
infoItem.description: Each bar or dot in graph represents a different surgeon. Results for each outcome are always presented in descending order. Your personal results are presented in red.

infoItem.label: Which surgeons are included? Why can't I see my results?
infoItem.description: To be included in any graph, you must have at least 20 cases that are eligible and provide relevant data. For example, imagine that you treated 4 cases a year for 10 years. You would be able to see results for "show my results for the entire cohort" but only be represented on a graph with the option "show my results for the last 5 years" if there was no missing data for that endpoint and the factors used to adjust results. If there is missing data for your patients in this scenario, you will see the results of other surgeons but your results will not be displayed.

This issue is particular pertinent if you start choosing options. For example, you may have treated hundreds of patients in your career, but if you select to look at estimated blood loss in laparoscopic surgery patients treated in the last two years, your result would only be shown if you had at least 20 recently treated laparoscopic surgery patients who provided data for the endpoint in question.

infoItem.label: I get a note stating that there are a limited number of events for analysis. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: All graphs do not use the same statistical method to make adjustments. When there are few events distributed amongst many surgeons, the method used to make adjustments is slightly different. The method used tends to make high performing surgeons look slightly worse and gives improved results to surgeons with poor outcomes. In other words, results for all surgeons tend to be pushed toward the mean.

infoItem.label: I get a note stating that there is a limited amount of data for this outcome. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: When there are very few events distributed among a couple of surgeons or when very few patients have the necessary information for risk adjustment, there is not enough data for case-mix adjustment. In this situation, raw, unadjusted rates are presented. These rates should be interpreted with caution as they may be impacted by case mix.

infoItem.label: I get an error message that not enough data are available. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: A graph may not be available if there are insufficient events for statistical analysis. If there were not enough patients treated within a specified time point, then a model cannot be created and results will not be shown.

infoItem.label: Can I use these results for research?
infoItem.description: These results are provided for operational feedback only. If you are interested in developing a study based on the results found through Amplio, please contact Andrew Vickers.

infoItem.label: Build My Own Graph
infoItem.description: You can explore your results by choosing any two outcomes to plot against each other. The only exceptions is Volume, which has been excluded to maintain surgeon anonymity.

infoItem.label: I get a note about the significance of difference between surgeons. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: Amplio reports generally show differences between surgeons. However, it would not be unexpected to see variations in outcome even if there were no true differences between surgeons. To give an obvious example, if 5 surgeons tossed a coin a hundred times, and Amplio showed that one surgeon threw heads 55% of the time whereas another only had 45% turn up heads, that couldn't be taken to mean that some surgeons were better at coin tossing than others. Accordingly, the Amplio software runs analyses to assess whether the differences shown between surgeons are compatible with chance. In the vast majority of cases, the data clearly indicate that chance is not a good explanation for the differencesobserved, that there are likely true differences in outcomes between clinicians. However, in some cases, we do not find evidence that differences are greater than would be expected by chance.

infoItem.label: I get a note stating that there is not enough data to test for difference between surgeons. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: It becomes increasingly difficult to assess whether differences between surgeons are greater than would be expected by chance when data is scarce. So this test is only performed when there is sufficient data for the result to be meaningful. You may thus be able to see test results for show my results for the entire cohort but not when you select show my results for the last 2 years. There may still be considerable variation in the results but there is not enough data to test whether these differences are significant.

infoItem.label: Complication Rates
infoItem.description: , defined as the proportion of patients with one or more complication of grade 3 or higher after surgery. As different types of surgeries (upper abdominal surgery, bowel resection, overall) may have markedly different rates of complications, rates are calculated and shown separately for each type of surgery. The variables used to adjust are age, stage, ASA score, BMI, OR tumor index, serous histology, preoperative albumin and preoperative ca125.

infoItem.label: Debulking Rates against Complication Rates.
infoItem.description: As different types of debulking (optimal, debulking) may have markedly different rates of complications, rates are calculated and shown separately for each type of debulking. The variables used to adjust are age, stage, ASA score, BMI, OR tumor index, serous histology, preoperative albumin and preoperative ca125.

infoItem.label: Estimated Blood Loss
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients who lose more than 500 mL, or, separately, lose more than 1000 mL. The variables used to adjust are age, stage, ASA score, BMI, OR tumor index, serous histology and preoperative albumin

infoItem.label: Resection Rates
infoItem.description: The rate at which upper abdominal surgery and bowel resection was performed. Upper abdominal surgery is defined as diaphragm stripping or resection, liver resection, splectomy, distal pancreatomy, cholescystectomy, partial gastrectomy or resection of porta hepatis disease. Bowel resection includes small bowel resection and large bowel resection. The variables used to adjust are age, stage, ASA score, BMI, OR tumor index, serous histology and preoperative albumin.

infoItem.label: Time to Chemotherapy
infoItem.description: For patients who received chemotherapy within 9 months of surgery, rates of receiving chemotherapy within 30 days of surgery and within 45 days of surgery. The variables used to adjust are age, stage, ASA score, BMI, OR tumor index, serous histology and preoperative albumin. Additionally, because complications can lead to delays to postoperative chemotherapy treatment, comparisons are made separately with and without adjusting for complications of grade 3 or higher

infoItem.label: Surgical Volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Survival Rate
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients who survive within a particular number of years after surgery. The variables used to adjust are age, stage, grade, ASA score, BMI, OR tumor index, serous histology, preoperative albumin, preoperative platelets, ascites, family history of breast or ovarian cancer, diabetes and hypertension.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for the entire cohort / past 5 years.
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated after the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Recurrence rate.
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, gender, grade, nodal status, and pathologic stage.

infoItem.label: Cancer-Specific Death.
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, gender, grade, nodal status, and pathologic stage.

infoItem.label: Overall Survival.
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, gender, grade, nodal status, and pathologic stage.

infoItem.label: 30-Day Mortality.
infoItem.description: This is defined as a death within 30 days of surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, BMI, and ASA

infoItem.label: Major Complication.
infoItem.description: This is defined as any complication with a grade ≥ 3 that occurred within 90 days of surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, BMI, ASA, neoadjuvant radiation, and prior abdominal surgery.

infoItem.label: Length of stay
infoItem.description: Length of stay is calculated as the number of nights a patient stays in the hospital after surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, BMI, ASA and pathological stage.

infoItem.label: Length of stay: discharge rates
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients discharged after a particular period of time. For example, a rate of 73% at 10 days, means that 73% of patients are discharged after 10 days. The variables used to adjust are: age, BMI, ASA and pathological stage.

infoItem.label: Total Number of Nodes Removed
infoItem.description: This is defined as the total number lymph nodes removed. The variables used to adjust are: age, BMI, ASA, prior abdominal surgey and pathological stage.

infoItem.label: Nodal Positivity
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients who had 1 or more positive lymph nodes found. The variables used to adjust are: age, BMI, ASA, prior abdominal surgery, and pathological stage.

infoItem.label: Soft Tissue Margins
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients who had positive soft tissue margins. Note that this is only soft tissue margin and does not include other margins such as urethral or ureter. The variables used to adjust are: age, gender, grade, nodal status, and pathologic stage.

infoItem.label: Surgical volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: High risk patients.
infoItem.description: The number of patients treated defined as high risk (≥ pT2 or ≥ pT3). There are no adjustments for case mix.

infoItem.label: Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients with muscle invasive cancer (≥ pT2) who received neoadjuvant chemotherapy. There are no adjustments for case mix.

infoItem.label: Clinical Trial Enrollments
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients who were referred to any clinical trial. There are no adjustments for case mix.

infoItem.label: Two year recurrence-free rate.
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients treated more than 27 months prior who have data on recurrence status at 2 years or after and are recurrence free.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for the last 1 year / 2 years / 5 years
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated after the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Recurrence and survival rates at 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 years
infoItem.description: You can specify the time at which recurrence or survival is estimated. If you specify, for example, 2 years, you obtain adjusted estimates for the probability of your patients' remaining free of recurrence or alive at 2 years.

infoItem.label: Complication Rate
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients with one or more post-op complication of grade 3 or higher separately for any type of complication, complications involving leaks and complications involving abscesses. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Neoadjuvant Therapy Rate
infoItem.description: For patients with stage T3 preoperatively, the proportion of those patients who received neoadjuvant therapy. The variables used to adjust are age and comorbidities.

infoItem.label: Positive Margin
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients with positive surgical margins. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Number of Nodes Removed
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Low Number of Nodes Removed
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients for whom fewer than 15 nodes were removed. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Estimated Blood Loss
infoItem.description: As different types of surgical approaches may have markedly different rates of estimated blood loss, rates are calculated and shown separately for open, robotic and laparoscopic surgery. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: High Estimated Blood Loss
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients who lose more than 250 mL, or, separately, more than 500 mL. As different types of surgical approaches may have markedly different rates of estimated blood loss, rates are calculated and shown separately for open, robotic and laparoscopic surgery. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Operative Time
infoItem.description: As different types of surgical approaches may have markedly different rates of operative time, rates are calculated and shown separately for open, robotic and laparoscopic surgery. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay Discharge Rates
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients discharged after a particular period of time. For example, a rate of 60% at 7 days means that 60% of patients were discharged 7 or more days after surgery. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Surgical Volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Minimally-Invasive Surgery Rate
infoItem.description: Defined as the proportion of patients who were treated with laparoscopic or robotic surgery. The variables used to adjust are T stage, N stage, location of cancer and use of neoadjuvant therapy.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for the entire cohort / past 5 years / past 2 years / past year.
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated after the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Estimated Blood Loss
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status (pathological grade 3 disease, clear cell histology, carcinosarcoma histology, serous histology or endometrioid histology and pathological grade 2 disease), and BMI.

infoItem.label: High Estimated Blood Loss Rates
infoItem.description: Blood loss > 250 mL or >500 mL for open surgery and blood loss > 100 mL or > 500 mL for minimally invasive surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay
infoItem.description: Length of stay is calculated as the number of nights a patient stays in the hospital after surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status and BMI.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay: Discharge Rates
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients discharged after a particular period of time. For example, a rate of 73% at 48 hours, means that 73% of patients are discharged after 48 hours. The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Operative Time
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Nodal Positivity
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients that had positive nodes removed (pathological stage IIIC disease). The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Postoperative Complications
infoItem.description: A complication (see Appendix for list of complications) following surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Sentinel Lymph Node
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients who had sentinel lymph nodes removed. The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Surgical Site Infections
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Total Number of Nodes Removed
infoItem.description: This is defined as the total number of aortic and pelvic nodes removed in patients who did not have sentinel lymph nodes removed. The variables used to adjust are: age and BMI.

infoItem.label: Minimally-Invasive Surgery
infoItem.description: This is the rate at which minimally-invasive surgery was performed. The variables used to adjust are: are, high risk status, and BMI.

infoItem.label: Surgical Volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Show my results for open surgery or minimally-invasive surgery
infoItem.description: You may want to look at how your results vary depending on the type of surgery you perform. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated with the specified surgery type.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for the last 1 year / 2 years / 5 years
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated within the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for high or low risk patients
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your results for certain subsets of patients. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons with low or high risk cancer. High risk cancer was defined as: (a) Pathological Grade 3, (b) Clear Cell Histology, (c) Carcinosarcoma Histology, (d) Serous Histology, (e) Endometrioid Histology and Pathological Grade 2

infoItem.label: Post-operative GFR
infoItem.description: This is GFR function at two days, two weeks, six weeks, six months, and one year. The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Adequate Kidney Function
infoItem.description: Adequate function is defined as a GFR 60. The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Ischemia Time
infoItem.description: Rates are only available for partial nephrectomies. The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Estimated Blood Loss
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Complications
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Major Complication
infoItem.description: This is defined as any complication with a grade 3. The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay
infoItem.description: Length of stay is calculated as the number of nights a patient stays in the hospital after surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay: Discharge Rates
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients discharged after a particular period of time. For example, a rate of 23% at four days, means that 23% of patients are discharged after four days. The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Operative Room Time
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Surgical Margin Status
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, comorbidities, gender, preoperative GFR, and tumor size.

infoItem.label: Partial Nephrectomies
infoItem.description: This is the rate at which partial nephrectomies were performed. The variables used to adjust are: tumor size.

infoItem.label: GFR reporting rate
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients for whom follow-up data on GFR is available. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Surgical Volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Low Risk Surgery Rates
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients that had a low risk tumor defined as: age > 75 and tumor 3cm OR age > 70 and tumor 3cm and ASA of III/IV. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for the last 1 year / 2 years / 5 years
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated within the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Show my results for open / robotic / laparoscopic surgeons.
infoItem.description: For most outcomes, you can choose to show your results to one or more categories of surgery. These options will only include patients both your own and for other surgeons treated with the specified type of surgery.

infoItem.label: I get a note about the significance of difference between surgeons. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: Amplio reports generally show differences between surgeons. However, it would not be unexpected to see variations in outcome even if there were no true differences between surgeons. To give an obvious example, if 5 surgeons tossed a coin a hundred times, and Amplio showed that one surgeon threw heads 55% of the time whereas another only had 45% turn up heads, that couldn't be taken to mean that some surgeons were better at coin tossing than others. Accordingly, the Amplio software runs analyses to assess whether the differences shown between surgeons are compatible with chance. In the vast majority of cases, the data clearly indicate that chance is not a good explanation for the differencesobserved, that there are likely true differences in outcomes between clinicians. However, in some cases, we do not find evidence that differences are greater than would be expected by chance.

infoItem.label: I get a note stating that there is not enough data to test for difference between surgeons. What does this mean?
infoItem.description: It becomes increasingly difficult to assess whether differences between surgeons are greater than would be expected by chance when data is scarce. So this test is only performed when there is sufficient data for the result to be meaningful. You may thus be able to see test results for show my results for the entire cohort but not when you select show my results for the last 2 years. There may still be considerable variation in the results but there is not enough data to test whether these differences are significant.

infoItem.label: Surgical Volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Complication Rates
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients with one or more post-operative complication of grade 3 or higher separately for any type of complication, pancreatic leaks, delayed gastric empty and wound infection. As different types of diseases may have markedly different rates of complications, rates are calculated and shown separately for pancreatic cancer cases and all other diseases that lead to a pancreatomy. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: Positive Margin Rates
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients among pancreatic cancer cases with positive surgical margins. The variable used to adjust is tumor size.

infoItem.label: Estimated Blood Loss
infoItem.description: The amount of estimated blood loss during surgery. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: High Estimated Blood Loss Rates
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients who lose more than 500mL or, separately, more than 1000mL. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: Operative Time
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index and diabetes.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay
infoItem.description: The number of nights a patient stays in the hospital after surgery. As different types of diseases may have markedly different lengths of stay, rates are calculated and shown separately for pancreatic cancer cases and all other diseases that lead to a pancreatomy. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: Length of Stay Discharge Rates
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients discharged after a particular period of time. For example, a rate of 23% at four days means that 23% of patients are discharged after 4 days. As different types of diseases may have markedly different lengths of stay, rates are calculated and shown separately for pancreatic cancer cases and all other diseases that lead to a pancreatomy. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: Mortality within 90 Days
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients who die within 90 days after surgery. As different types of diseases may have markedly different survival, rates are calculated and shown separately for pancreatic cancer cases and all other diseases that lead to a pancreatomy. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: Survival Rate
infoItem.description: The proportion of patients who survive within a particular number of years after surgery. As different types of diseases may have markedly different survival, rates are calculated and shown separately for pancreatic cancer cases and all other diseases that lead to a pancreatomy. The variables used to adjust are age, body mass index, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.

infoItem.label: Show my results for the entire cohort /past 5 years/ past 2 years / past year
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients - both your own and for other surgeons - treated after the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Show my results for the entire cohort / pancreatic cancer cases / others
infoItem.description: You can choose to include all patients, only those who were pancreatic cancer cases or only those who were not pancreatic cancer cases.

infoItem.label: Surgical Margins
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status.

infoItem.label: Length of stay.
infoItem.description: Length of stay is calculated as the number of nights a patient stays in the hospital after surgery. The variables used to adjust are: age, pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status.

infoItem.label: Length of stay: discharge rates
infoItem.description: This is defined as the proportion of patients discharged after a particular period of time. For example, a rate of 73% at 24 hours, means that 73% of patients are discharged after 24 hours. The variables used to adjust are: age, pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status.

infoItem.label: Operating Room Time
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status. As different approaches (open, laparoscopic, robotic) have markedly different OR times, comparisons are only made within a particular approach. If you use several different approaches (e.g. robotic and open) results will be displayed only for the pertinent surgeries (e.g. if you choose to see results for robotic), the OR time only for your robotic procedures will be displayed.

infoItem.label: Blood loss
infoItem.description: The variables used to adjust are: age, pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status. As different approaches (open, laparoscopic, robotic) have markedly different rates of blood loss, comparisons are only made within a particular approach. If you use several different approaches (e.g. robotic and open) results will be displayed only for the pertinent surgeries (e.g. if you choose to see results for robotic, blood loss only for your robotic procedures will be displayed).

infoItem.label: Two year biochemical recurrence reporting rates
infoItem.description: Patients treated more than 27 months prior are considered to have been followed-up with respect to BCR if they have had a PSA measurement more than 21 months after surgery or were known to have recurred before 24 months.

infoItem.label: One year functional outcome reporting rates
infoItem.description: Patients treated more than 13 months prior are considered to have been followed-up with respect to functional outcomes if they have had both erectile and urinary function measured more than 10 months after surgery.

infoItem.label: Surgical volume
infoItem.description: The number of cases treated. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Recurrence rate
infoItem.description: Biochemical recurrence is defined as a PSA measurement more than 30 days after surgery above 0.2 ng/mL. The patient is also considered to have experienced a BCR if they have been treated for a recurrence (e.g. hormones, radiation). The variables used to adjust are: pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and preoperative PSA.

infoItem.label: Continence.
infoItem.description: Continence is defined as a score of 17 or greater on the patient-assessed Prostate QOL Survey, or, where patient data are not available, a score of 1 on the surgeon assessed Urinary Function Survey. The variables used to adjust are: preoperative surgeon-assessed urinary function, age at surgery, pathologic Gleason grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status.

infoItem.label: Potency
infoItem.description: Potency is defined as a score of 22 or greater on the patient-assessed Prostate QOL Survey, or, where patient data are not available, a score of 1 or 2 on the surgeon assessed Erectile Function Survey. The variables used to adjust are: preoperative surgeon-assessed erectile function, age at surgery, pathologic Gleason Grade, SVI, ECE, LNI, and erectile nerve sparing status.

infoItem.label: Life expectancy
infoItem.description: Life expectancy is calculated based on patients age and comorbidity. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Recurrence risk
infoItem.description: Five year recurrence risk is calculated using preoperative PSA, biopsy Gleason grade, and clinical stage. There is no adjustment for case mix.

infoItem.label: Low Risk Cases
infoItem.description: Low risk cases are defined if the patient meets any of the following criteria: (a) Low Risk (Clinical Stage ≤ T2a and Gleason ≤ 6 and PSA ≤ 10),(b) Intermediate Risk (Clinical Stage T2b/T2c or Gleason = 7 or PSA 10-20, but Stage < T3 and Gleason < 8 and PSA < 20) and age ≥ 70.

There may be good reasons for surgery in a patient who meets these criteria. As such, rates of low risk cases are meant to be comparative: it is not expected that any surgeon should have a zero rate of low risk cases.

infoItem.label: Show my results only for the last 6 months / 1 year / 5 years
infoItem.description: You may want to look at your more recent results, for example, if you changed your technique. This option only includes patients both your own and for other surgeons treated after the time you specify.

infoItem.label: Recurrence rates at 1, 2 or 5 years
infoItem.description: You can specify the time at which recurrence is estimated. If you specify, for example, 2 years, you obtain adjusted estimates for the probability of your patients' remaining free of recurrence at 2 years.

infoItem.label: Functional recovery rates at 3 or 6 months, 1 or 2 years
infoItem.description: You can specify the time at which recovery of urinary and erectile function is estimated. If you specify, for example, 6 months, you obtain adjusted estimates for the probability of patients' regaining erectile function by 6 months.

infoItem.label: Show my results for open / laparoscopic / robotic surgeons
infoItem.description: For most outcomes, you can choose to show your results to one or more categories of surgery. These options will only include patients both your own and for other surgeons treated with the specified type of surgery. The exception is blood loss and OR time: these analyses treat patients separately depending on the type of surgery, and it is only possible to compare results to a single approach.

infoItem.label: Show my results for low risk, low/intermediate risk, intermediate/high risk, or high risk patients.
infoItem.description: You can choose to include all patients or only those in certain risk groups. Low risk" includes patients with ≤ T2a and Gleason ≤ 6 and PSA < 10 ng / ml. Intermediate risk includes patients with T2b/T2c or Gleason = 7or PSA 10-20 ng / ml. High risk includes patients with ≥ T3 or Gleason ≥ 8 or PSA > 20.
